top_comment.text:
People associate colors with more than just color though.  For example: 
 Red is usually considered an angry color, Pink a girl color.  We 
understand brighter and darker colors.  

Of course, there are our own individual relationships that we develop that 
we assign color to.  We also understand the relationship between color and 
physical forces like wavelengths.  Sure, someone else's red might be 
another person's green or blue, but since the relationships with color are 
close to identical with few individual differences, the question is 
meaningless.  Our brains develop very close to the same way, so it's not a 
ridiculous assumption to say that red to me looks the same as it does to 
you if the part of the brain that recognized color got swapped with yours.﻿
top_comment.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text:
True, but that's my point in that we don't just experience the sight of a 
color.  Colors represent associations.  They represent associations with 
each other, brightness intensity, and specific events.  The only thing the 
explanatory gap fails to cover is the brain's exact interpretation of a 
color.  As I said, it's possible in theory that my red is someone else's 
green, but considering the ratio of our rods and cones, it's just very 
difficult to justify it looking any different to any other person.

top_comment.text:
*Could you ever assess relative subjective qualia?*
*And tell if my Red is the same as your Red?*

Many of you would have seen this great little video from Vsauce that 
discusses subjective conscious experiences or qualia. 

And many of you will be familiar with the fact that colour is an "illusion" 
created by our brains - in the sense that objects in the world do not have 
any intrinsic property of colour, and merely reflect or emit light / 
electromagnetic radiation of different energy, frequency, and wavelength . 
. . which in turn is picked up by photoreceptors (proteins) in your retinal 
neurons that are sensitive to those energies and which convert those 
signals into specific neuronal firing patterns. And there is no intrinsic 
colour to a neuronal firing pattern. (Or is there?)

This of course relates directly to the "Hard Problem" of consciousness, 
which is concerned with how physical mechanisms in the brain can produce 
subjective conscious experiences and qualia like the colour "Red". 

*Question*
But what I'm pondering here is whether you could ever assess the relative 
subjective qualia between two people? Not that by looking at someone or 
their brain you could ever *know what it is **like* to be them, but simply 
gain insight into whether their subjective experience might be similar to 
your own. 

*Experiment*
It is well known that if you show someone a pattern in their visual field, 
e.g. a black star on white background, and scan their brains while they are 
viewing it (~fMRI) you will see a star-like pattern of brain activity 
occurring in their visual cortex. The physical object / pattern being 
viewed is represented as or is mapped onto a corresponding pattern of 
neuronal activity.

My question concerns taking this experimental data from scans of many 
people, to see if you can see difference in the pattern of neuronal 
activity for different brains viewing the same physical object or pattern. 
Do they all map cleanly and distinctly, in the sense of physical star 
patterns always forming star patterns of neuronal activity? Are some 
people's resulting neuronal star patterns more intense than others?

Could you extend this to physical scenes that hold not star patterns but an 
entire visual field composed of bright red light (from a screen for 
example) to determine what parts of the brain light up in different people 
in response to red light? Blue light? Green light? 

And could you compare the brain activity in each person that occurred when 
exposed to bright red, dull red, different intensities of red? 

*Assess*
Finally, with a large data set comprised of brain activity from different 
people exposed to different physical stimulus (concentrating on colour to 
keep it simple) at different intensity . . . could you not assess whether 
people appeared to be experiencing the same subjective qualia as one 
another?

*Imply* that their "Red" was the same as your "Red"? 

Something along the lines of:
These regions in different people correspond to red, those for blue, and 
these other for green. This is the activity that occurs for more intense 
stimulus, that for less intense. Aha it seems that in this population of 
people this red screen induced an "intense red" activity pattern but in the 
other group of people it induced only a "standard red" activity pattern and 
in this small subset it actually induced a "blue" activity pattern while 
this weird outlier dude had his auditory cortex light up in E-major. etc 
etc. 

Could you ever know? 
Could you ever gain a degree of confidence that this was so? ﻿
top_comment.author: Mark Bruce

I had an interesting time in my early 20's when one night I was shocked to 
find an arm lying on the floor next to me in my living room.
For the life of me, I couldn't figure out who's it was.
It seriously freaked me out for about 20 minutes, until I realised it was 
mine.
I had taken quite a lot of strong drugs though :-)
To this day I still have powerfully lucid moments of disconnection from 
(particularly) my left arm.
It's proved occasionally useful insofar that odd jobs I've been rubbish at 
when using my left hand (don't be rude!) have been possible to improve by 
literally training my left arm/hand as if it were not mine.
P.S. In case anyone reading this doesn't already know: I was diagnosed 
Schizophrenic in my mid to late 20's, so "weird" may as well be my middle 
name \o/

comments.text:
I am going to sidestep the debate about whether my red is the same as your 
red. This question doesn't interest me as much because if you look at it 
from a functional perspective, it doesn't matter that your red isn't the 
same color as my red. What matters is whether there are differences between 
the subconscious connections you make with the color I perceive as red and 
the connections I make.

Personally I don't think we'll ever know exactly how others experience 
anything subjectively. We might be able to get very close but to truly 
understand how someone else sees red you would have to become him.

The majority of people on this planet are conditioned to connect red with 
love because centuries ago we made the heart, which is actually greyish but 
just happens to look red because of the blood being pumped through it, a 
symbol of love. Most likely because we noticed hearts beat faster when the 
owner is aroused?

Red is danger, if your body is losing a lot of red, you are in serious 
trouble. Red is a very emotionally intense color. It enhances human 
metabolism, increases respiration rate, and raises blood pressure. It has 
very high visibility, which is why stop signs, stoplights, and fire 
equipment are usually painted red.

The majority of people also connects red with warmth. Perhaps a leftover 
from the time we discovered fire and gathered around campfires? fire, 
yellow/orange/red = hot. Blue is actually even hotter and more energetic 
but by the time we discovered how to make fires this hot, red had already 
started representing warmth? something hot is also dangerous so there is 
nice overlap there. 

Red is the color of fire and blood, it is associated with energy, war, 
danger, strength, power, determination as well as passion, desire, and 
love. This is the kind of stuff we can semi-objectively agree on (within 
cultures). 

So that's the stuff we can agree on, still I think there is a lot of 
individual coloring going on (pun intended ;)) If you happen to have had 
bad experiences with red (red objects, people wearing red, ...) this might 
have an effect on how you see the color. Perhaps a particular kind of red 
reminds me of my grandfather who died wearing his red suit which in turn 
creates feelings of loss and nostalgia. How would I find out what you feel 
when seeing red?

If I run an instance of your mind experiencing red as a subset of my own, I 
have to make sure that they run completely separate from each other in 
order to not corrupt the data with my own experiences of red. In fact, to 
truly experience how you see red, I(you) wouldn't be allowed to know you 
are a simulation. I would have turn off myself completely and only be you 
and you are not allowed to realize you are not really you so that means 
prior to setup I would have to hack visual cues, create a digital avatar 
that matches the simulation's expectations, engineer a past to create the 
illusion of continuous experience, ... lots of work. :p

But now the real problem, if I have to keep your experience and 
interpretations separate from myself then how can *I* ever experience 
someone else as myself? Whether you experience the simulation in real time, 
render it virtually from stored brain patterns, you have direct access to 
someone else's memory, ... any situation you can come up with, the second 
you bring in your own point of view, the experience becomes less pure, 
tainted with your own views.

Not to mention that all this sounds rather dangerous because once I am you, 
how would I remember I am not really you? Prior to setup you could set up a 
kill time for the simulation but still... being someone else could be one 
hell of a drug. Perhaps you would fall in love with your own view of 
someone else's memories? Why would I want to be my old self again if I 
really like my romanticized and idealized version of what it's like being 
you? What if not being allowed to be you I become depressed about being me? 
What if you can't stop me? Now that I sort of know how you tick, I don't 
need you anymore. :p 

/far out there ;)
comments.author: Koen De Paus

comments.text:
I think there are three ways of addressing this problem in light of what we 
know from cognitive neuroscience: formalisation of 
stimuli, behavioural responses to stimuli, and consideration of the 
complexity of consciousness.

Firstly phenomena such as the geometry of a star (which can in some brain 
damage induced cases of blind sight be topographically mapped on the 
striate cortex without any declarative conscious experience of the shape 
itself) can – at the abstract level of this discussion – be formalised, or 
otherwise described in precise terms ( e.g. 5 points, closed outline, 
 etc), which demonstrate equivalence between aspects of our experience.

Considering conscious experience at the level of less tangible qualia 
(redness of red) we can learn a lot from behavioural experiments. For 
example we know that there are gender differences in perception of colour; 
males and females are typically slightly more sensitive to different parts 
of the colour spectrum. Additionally we know that women tend of respond 
differently to men who are wearing (or visually accompanied by) the colour 
red, but not vice versa.

This last example hints at what I think is the real problem with qualia 
which is that conscious experience, both at the seemingly irreducible 
subjective level, and at the neurological level, is incredibly complex. How 
do you know that your own mental representation of red is that same from 
one moment to the next, you've got nothing to compare it to (since 
recalling it and seeing is are essentially the same thing at this level). 
Do you see red the same when you're anxious and so primed to respond to it 
more emotionally, isn't the emotional response part of the experience of 
the colour? Aren't all your personal learned associations of a colour part 
of your experience of that colour. This would suggest that in the same way 
that you can expect a fair amount of consistency between 
our primitive experiences from one moment to the next, we can expect a 
similar degree of consistency between one human and the next (given that 
our brains are fundamentally pretty similar). However you can not expect 
any two experiences of anything to be identical, due to the highly personal 
nature of the formation of every experience as a whole and 
the inseparability of each element of an experience, or in other words, due 
to the chaotic nature of the systems that bring about consciousness.

wired differently. But my understanding, and from what I've read, suggests 
that larger structures are conserved and similar across people e.g. the 
same area destroyed by stroke in different people typically results in the 
same cognitive pathology. So while slightly different the basic processing 
of features / stimuli should be quite similar and multiple brain scan 
studies suggest that a looking at a star on paper induces a star-like 
pattern of neural activity in all people.

comments.text:
"colors are same for everyone because they are defined by exact proportions 
of RGB combo which is the international standard".

RGB is not the international standard for defining color.  The colorimetry 
tristimulus values x, y, z are the international standards for defining 
color (e.g., the common CIE1931).

"so if 255,0,0 is RGB Combination of red color which I perceive, it is 
possible that you perceive it  255,1,1 or 255,2,1 or 255,1,3 but it is 
impossible to see it as 0,255,0 (which stands for green) as it is a very 
huge difference."

255,0,0 isn't a color.  Oh, it's called a color in computer science, but 
only because we work with RGB devices and normally can only specify to that 
level--but in more precise terms, if you render 255,0,0 on your 
monitor--and I render 255,0,0 on mine; then there's not only no *guarantee* 
our monitors rendered the same color, but it's *unlikely* in practice that 
they did.

Speaking of human perception in terms of RGB is even worse.  Human vision 
simply doesn't work that way.  Our cones--which are *not* RGB devices--are 
sensitive to an entire spectra of light.  But our brain never gets the pure 
signals from the cones--before it even travels down the optic nerve it's 
mixed into three different color channels by ganglia; the red/green 
channel, the yellow/blue channel, and the lightness/darkness channel.  The 
latter is special in that it can be perceived mixed; the former two 
nominally cannot.  However, under certain extremely controlled unnatural 
conditions, subjects can be made to see what are called "Martian Colors" 
like reddish-green.

So, I have two very technical and scientifically supported reasons to say 
that what you're saying is gibberish: (1) RGB isn't a standard, (2) even if 
it were standardized, it's irrelevant to perception.  Instead, I offer that 
you need to research color theory and human vision quite a bit more before 
confusing what you think you know with science.
comments.author: Forrest Fyre

comments.text:
+Funnysterste Actually, it's 100% correct. We all share a basic genetic 
blueprint, true, that's what defines us a species. For instance, most 
people have two eyes, one nose, and one mouth, and they are generally 
arranged in that order descending the face. Some people have green eyes, 
some people have blue eyes, and some people have brown eyes. Now, even 
though all these people have two eyes, obviously something is different in 
their respective genetic compositions to alter the pigmentation of their 
iris. Hence, biodiversity.
To address your original comment, I believe you may be misunderstanding the 
question that is being asked in the video title. It's a question about the 
internal workings of your mind, or your internal perception. If a group of 
people were to observe a light bulb covered in a transparent red film in an 
otherwise dark room, every single one of them would have light entering 
their eye with an identical wavelength. They would, because their genetic 
make up is similar, all be observing light with a wavelength of 
approximately 650nm. What the real thought provoking question is here is 
would all of them perceive it the same way, internally? What's to say that 
the color my brain has assigned to red isn't the color your brain has 
assigned to blue? That is to say, even though we are seeing the same 
wavelengths, the same light, our brains may have assigned different mental 
shadings to accompany it.
Of course now we run into the problem of qualia, and if you can't grasp the 
concept from the video itself I doubt I have the linguistic talent to open 
your eyes to it (pun intended). I hope, though, that this may have helped 
to explain it.
comments.author: Scott Merrill

comments.text:
Lol I think you missed the whole point. A persons perceptions of color can 
be fundamentally different without anyone else even knowing. When we 
describe an object as red we're basically saying that the object reflects 
light of a certain wavelength, specifically, light at the red end of the 
spectrum i.e. around 400nm. As long as we all agree that objects that 
reflect that wavelength of light are to be called "red", we can 
successfully communicate. However, since language can't communicate private 
subjective experience, but rather, only information about the external 
world, we can never know what its like to experience the world from the 
perspective of someone else. In other words you can't experience the same 
exact thing as I'm experiencing because we're two different people, and you 
can't communicate the nature of your experiences because they're part of 
your own internal experience and not the external reality that we can all 
perceive.

comments.text:
+hikariheir To add to this, warm and cool are references to fire or lava, 
and water or ice. Fire and lava generally being shades of red, yellow and 
orange, and water or ice being shades of blue, cyan or even white or 
transparent, which means that saying red is warm, is like saying lava is 
red.

There are already digital devices that measure brain waves and transmit 
information such as how interested you are in what you're looking at. I'm 
sure someday in the future of humanity, we will be able to pinpoint the 
brain waves that show us what colour we're experiencing, and therefor be 
able to transmit that colour to a monitor. If we see our red...our red 
comes up on the monitor. Of course, that red could be green to others, or 
blue, or yellow, etc. I think this would be the closest possible way of 
finding out if we all see the same colours, or not, and if not, how 
different they can be.

For one, I understand how TommyEdison feels trying to learn what a colour 
is, or how it looks. I understand the concept of seeing different reds to 
someone else, but I can't wrap my head around the fact that there's a 
possibility that when someone looks at me, they see me as light green or 
blue instead of a light tan. I understand that I could look like that to 
them. I think the whole idea I can't wrap my head around is the fact that 
if I looked at someone and saw green or blue, I would probably freak out. 
And I would probably react the same way if a device could transmit to a 
monitor what colour someone saw, and I saw something different to what I 
saw. Could you imagine having green or blue skin? Could you imagine looking 
at fire and seeing purple? Or looking at the sky and seeing red? It's all 
hard to think about, but the fact that it's possible is so easy to 
understand.

comments.text:
I have to disagree. Colour is a subjective but correlated experience. 
However, high degree of correlation does not necessarily mean we experience 
the same "colour", even if we call it by the same name. Hence illusion. 
You may be conflating colour and wavelength. Wavelength only becomes the 
sensation of "colour" when it interacts with our receptors and processed by 
the mind. Colour does not exist by itself, in the way that wavelength does. 
Best we can do is create a standard and say "most people see this 
(colour)". 

You may want to look into Qualia vs Quantity. It's a fascinating 
distinction.

No one would know since they were always taught that that color was "red" 
it might still be your "pink" but, people may see light/dark at different 
levels, like that particular shade of red might appear lighter to you, 
making it seem pink, or brown might seem yellow. It's like how some people 
see better in the dark. What I mean is the change in color may happen 
faster for some people. Imagine yourself holding a hard plastic tube full 
of water, with a bubble of air in the center. Like this: /---( )---/ if you 
tip it slightly, the bubble will rise. The more you tip it, and the steeper 
the angle, the faster the bubble moves. What if for some people, the tube 
tilts at a steeper angle quicker? The bubble being how light or dark the 
color is. The people that have their tubes Tilt slower would see many 
shades of reddish colors as just red, where the people that have their 
tubes at the steeper angle that see the many reddish colors as dark red, 
light red, and pink. For example, there is a simulated test where on a 
screen a dark red color is getting lighter. Some people may think it starts 
to look pink quicker than others. I'm sorry if you don't understand, I hope 
you do though

top_comment.text:
This video (mostly in the first 3 minutes) explains the concept of qualia, 
or subjective experiences which we do not, and cannot truly share with any 
other person.  

When two people see light at the wavelength 650, they experience a color 
which they have both been trained to label "red".  Assuming neither person 
is colorblind, they can communicate about the color red, because the two 
distinct experiences are caused by the same stimuli.  An example of failed 
communication is the Japanese perception of the "go" street light as being 
"blue" not "green".  The color of their streetlights are 
not noticeably different from our own, but they have labelled it 
differently, and so we fail to communicate when faced with the same stimuli.

This led me to a thought experiment.  Assume an alien species with "perfect 
telepathy" approaches earth and attempts to communicate from deep space 
with a human in a mutual first contact scenario.  The two beings are not 
interacting in any physical measurable way, but can only transmit and 
receive "signals" to the mind.  The alien will be incapable of describing 
things as simple as shapes, let alone abstract concepts.  Each entity has 
constructed a model of a "square" in their mind and labelled it, and each 
might project their model into the other's mind.  However, without an 
accompanying reference in visual or tactile form, neither model will have 
any meaning to the other.

Take this a step further and consider a "superhuman" telepath.  Matt 
Parkman from heroes could "hear" words in his target's mind.  However, 
applying the above limitations, he would not hear words but rather a jumble 
of mental models.  That's not to say that it would be impossible for Matt 
to read minds, but he would have to use some parallel stimuli to make the 
correct mappings.  He could learn his target's mental models by 
telepathically perceiving while listening as they spoke words out loud. 
 However, each new person who he tried to read would have entirely 
different models.

This leads me to the conclusion that generalized telepathy in the 
traditional sense is impossible.  Each mind speaks its own language.  One 
need not develop the "mental shielding" of sci fi and fantasy, and only 
those nearest to you could hope to natively understand your mind after 
years of exposure.  On the other hand, telepathy in a technological sense 
may be only a few decades away, but it will consist of training your brain 
with a neural interface to use a common language, or a "network protocol".﻿
top_comment.author: Jeff Bishop

comments.text:
http://io9.com/5987567/brain+to+brain-interfaces-have-arrived-and-they-are-absolutely-mindblowing

This new experiment may provide evidence against my argument.
comments.author: Jeff Bishop

comments.text:
I generally agree with your arguments.  My main sticking point is that 
"instant access" (i.e. "magic") telepathy implies an unknown and generally 
unexplained method of perceiving thoughts.  This may or may not presuppose 
understanding of a lower level "language" from which thoughts are 
constructed.  It is entirely possible that this telepathy could manifest, 
not as understanding abstract thoughts of the target, but as experiencing 
the raw qualia of the target.

Alternatively, it could manifest as a translation layer.  Perhaps when I am 
thinking "red" and a telepath examines my thoughts, he gets his own 
internal experience of "red," without really delving into my subjective 
experience.  Essentially, this version of telepathy would be equivalent to 
speech.  Talking with your brain, if you will.

On the other hand, if it is a more mechanical process that essentially 
consists of reading electrical brain activity and converting that into 
useful information, I generally agree with you.  Certain general 
information ("this dude is real angry," "this lady is getting intense 
visual stimulation") would be immediately obvious because it is expressed 
commonly in all humans, but more specific information would require some 
calibration.
comments.author: Cary Collins

comments.text:
Consider the computer equivalent.  You are provided an unknown computer, 
consisting of memory and logic.  You as an engineer can examine the current 
state of the memory, and you can examine the logic circuitry connecting to 
the memory.  You can even perceive the changes in memory enacted by the 
logic.  I contend that there is no way of understanding anything that is in 
memory given these constraints.

However, once you can connect the input and output devices, and watch how 
the logic and memory circuits interact with input and output, you can begin 
to interpret the results in memory, and the process will be even faster if 
you are permitted to provide specific test data to the computer. 
 Unfortunately the next "unkown computer" would not necessarily have any 
compatibility and the learning process would begin anew.

Similarly your example of "thinking in English" would remain meaningless to 
the telepathic observer *until* you spoke or typed those words.  At that 
point, the telepath could begin to connect your words to the "word forming 
model" in your brain.  Interestingly they would have to examine a great 
number of examples to pry apart the word forming mental process from the 
idea forming process which precedes it in the sentence speaking exercise.

To your final point, I haven't ruled out telepathy at all.  What I have 
ruled out is the traditional "instant access" form of telepathy that 
appears in most scifi and fantasy.  In fact, I argue that telepathy is not 
only possible but inevitable using technological means.  What my argument 
shows, though, is that the theoretical "psychic telepathy" must follow the 
same rules as a not-so-distantly-theoretical "wifi telepathy".  We must 
either learn each individual's internal language, or we must agree upon 
common telepathic languages.  So if the telepath wished to do so they 
certainly *could* learn to perceive blue in the same way, but it would take 
a great deal of time spent studying a person's thought.
comments.author: Jeff Bishop

comments.text:
This doesn't necessarily rule out telepathy entirely.  Most of the time I'm 
thinking, I'm thinking in English.  There's no reason to believe a 
theoretical telepath couldn't understand that.  And as the video mentions, 
we don't have any proof that these concepts can't be communicated--we 
simply don't know how to communicate them.  It's possible that, were I a 
telepath, I could experience "blue" in the way that you experience it.
comments.author: Cary Collins

comments.text:
On the topic of language, I believe this is exactly how language is 
learned, by linking labels provided externally by your parents and the 
environment to mental models you've constructed.  You then begin to use the 
labels, and rely on feedback to constantly refine both your labels and your 
mental models.  

Occasionally those words can help create a mental model as well (such as 
this philosophical question we are now pondering) .  We then try to express 
that mental model, using labels we already share.  But no matter how hard I 
try, the mental model I've created from this question will never be 
transmitted into your mind intact.  You will have to construct your own 
model that we'll eventually agree to label, neither of us knowing for 
certain if we are talking about the same objective concept.
comments.author: Jeff Bishop

comments.text:
The video isn't saying that the color "blue" doesn't objectively exist, but 
that your mind doesn't store the objective wavelengths or the hue, 
saturation, and lightness of the color in its model of "blue". Your mind 
stores a subjective model that references a set of wavelengths that may be 
narrower or wider than the formal definition.  

Your mind may also categorize non-colors as "blue" and link them in your 
mental model.  

So when I say the word "blue", the mental model in my head, yours, and 
Joel's is slightly different.  It's possible that the differences are small 
and that you could extract a core similarity (say 475nm is similarly 
represented) by scanning our brains, but I suspect that your generalized 
brain scan would fail to do anything more than say "this person is thinking 
about an abstract visual stimulus ... and maybe about music (blues)".
comments.author: Jeff Bishop

comments.text:
+Russell Steen I'm not positive about this (my level of depth on this 
subject is only as deep as reading a lot of pop science articles on the 
subject) -- but every "mind reading" experiment I've read about has 
required significant training on the part of the system doing the reading, 
correlating real-world stimuli to neural firing patterns.

In one example that was making the rounds a year or two ago, researchers 
were able to create very crude "videos" of what the subject's seeing, by 
tapping into the V1 part of the visual cortex. Even in that very regular 
region, where firing patterns are well understood, they had to train the 
system separately for each subject. It seems almost inevitable that the 
"training problem" becomes more difficult as you move further up the neural 
hierarchy from raw inputs (V1 is only lightly processed from the optic 
nerve).

[I'm not commenting on the linked video, which I haven't watched, just the 
notion that cortical structure is similar enough across humans to have any 
hope of a "common neural language".]
comments.author: Joel Webber

comments.text:
I'll also kind of add that the video isn't so good.  It's almost a farce. 
 Color, for instance "blue", does exist, just like gravity does.  "Blue" is 
the common layman's term for a certain wavelength of light.  It is no more 
accurate to say "Color" does not exist than it is to say "Music" does not 
exist.  Music certainly does.  It is again, just a layman's term for sound 
waves matching certain patterns (with very loose criteria).  The fact that 
some people can't see blue doesn't mean it does not exist, any more than 
the existence of blind people negates the existence of the sun.

It's kind of like saying "heat" doesn't exist, there's this thing with 
energy and we just "call it heat"...

top_comment.text:
Too much here is given hyperbole on the 'mystery' of experience. However, 
there is not mystery, just lack of ability. Our own ability to mimic or 
understand doesnt exactly equate to a loss of potential. Even now, there 
are procedures in use and in development that can alter how a person 
perceives. Using these methods, you can mimic the same perceptual outcomes 
of others to experience the world as they do. 

You can see in rudimentary practice by "subjectively" experiencing 
something. If I tell you about snow, and explain all about it to you, but 
you never see it or experience it yourself, we can count it among the gap 
portrayed here. However, if I put a snowball in your hand, your 
understanding increasing drastically.

The basic idea is that this video puts all the emphasis on verbal 
communication, but forgets about visual, auditory, and other sensory 
methods of communication. (I separate verbal and auditory, because while 
auditory can encompass verbal it is not inclusive solely of it). I can 
describe the smell of an orange, but until you smell it you will not truly 
know it. I can describe the feeling of cold, but until you put your hand in 
something cold you will know it, and so forth. 

The difference in perception described here, where my red is not 
necessarily your red, is also measurable, even by today's methods. I can 
see how viewing a red strawberry will impact your mind and senses, what 
rods and cones are activated, etc, and see whether, for starters, the 
impact on your senses if the same as on mine. 

but you make object in saying that even if the physical results are the 
same, there may still be an underlying difference that is undetectable. In 
which you must then believe in the supernatural. In reality, all things are 
finite. No matter how numerous the factors at play are, there are still 
finite numbers of factors at play to determine my perception. It is only a 
matter of determining these factors and mimicking them to cause the 
mimicking of the perception as well. ﻿
top_comment.author: Conrad Cline

comments.text:
+Reynaldo Belfort
The point about music is that you can't generalize how people feel about a 
particular piece of music. I wouldn't put music into line with the general 
perceptions such as smelling, feeling, hearing, etc.
Emotions towards music is a learned behavior and (as I am quite sure about 
that) 100% depending on the individual's associations to it. This also 
explains why you have such a wide variety of musical styles and tastes. So 
if you claim that music or a certain melody or even just a note "blends", 
"mixes" or "wakes up", then you're making a claim that's probably not true 
for the majority of people.

There is a little sharing ground if you talk about specific musical 
dynamics, such as sudden shifts in pitches, rhythms or volume, but these, I 
would say, can be largely attributed to the general hearing perception and 
the eeriness of breaching a pattern that was expected. Humans are quite 
keen on pattern recognition and any disruption of such. But that goes far 
beyond the scope of your post. :)

you know its converted to signals carried by the optic nerve to your visual 
cortex? if you mean the signals made for blue light at your retinas are the 
same as mine for red light then i get it, its the likely situation that 
might occur to get a different experience if i'm in your head.

Its like this, blue is decoded as the "a" signal for you and for me that 
"a" signal means red color and my "b" signal is blue, it doesn't mean we

+Miss Terious It is not to that extreme he showed with the strawberry. It's 
more like shades of the same color we perceive as being the same between 
different people. My mom has trouble distinguishing between various shades 
of blue and purple while I do not. That means we perceive them differently. 
So the icon you use here has red lips, that red may seem more or less 
vibrant to me and you, it may have a more orange hue for me seen through 
your eyes but then again, we could see the exact same red. Seeing in an 
opposite wavelength of color is more rare and generally in color blindness 
it can actually be more "greyish" as certain light spectrums are not read 
correctly by the brain. 

The thing is, we can't really describe the difference accurately to each 
other as we've been taught this is THIS color. I can't tell you my red is 
more red than your red because we've both been taught THIS is red, this is 
true red, no matter what. But I can also never explain the exact way I see 
that certain color of red. Sure, I can say it's more orangey but you may or 
may not agree. It may be more orangey for me then it is for you. Our eyes 
and brains may pick up on different parts of it.

comments.text:
+Mantikore420 Honestly, while I would like him to be a little less vague, I 
don't believe he is necessarily promoting one view over another. I've 
watched five of his videos and it seems like he is trying to give a broad 
overview of the different hypothesis of the hows and whys of a given topic. 
It can be misleading to some, but to people who are scientifically savvy 
this is actually a very good overview of other hypotheses, even the invalid 
ones. Sometimes it's nice to know how other people think. 
     And on the topic of subjective experience, it is essentially 
impossible to know without a doubt that what I experience is the same as 
what you experience in certain circumstances, and while I haven't given it 
much thought, color does seem like a good example. Why doesn't it make 
sense that certain things exist purely in our head? A certain wave-length 
of light does not "create" red or green. And dogs do see colors differently 
than we do, as do cats. The question is do human beings see color 
differently from one another. I for one believe for all intents and 
purposes that we do experience the world the same way (except for the rare 
exceptions) as it would seem implausible that we evolved completely 
separate perceptions of the physical world. 
     And on that topic it is EXTREMELY implausible that an alien race would 
"feel" the same way we do. They would very likely feel pain, nausea, 
pleasure, but it doesn't change the fact that how they feel those things 
could be completely different from us. Physical injury could create a 
completely different sensation, yet serve the same purpose and elicit the 
same response as pain. We only experience physical sensation because they 
serve a purpose, there is no law or theory in physics that explains the 
sensation of pain. 
     I honestly don't really understand the materialist/immaterialist 
debate. I'll admit I honestly don't fully understand either one, mainly 
because while I have had debates with people in person, and even more 
online, I can't for the life of me see where either theory leads 
ideologically. Another example of a useless (and yet tested) hypothesis; 
you can't really prove the universe is a simulation and we're all just 
programmed any more than you can prove it isn't, so in the end does it 
really matter?
comments.author: Aaron L

There is nothing related to playing semantics when I am only referring to

is. An illusion is a sensory distortion that shows us how our brain 
interprets. Notice the distortion part? That distortion comes from the 
tricking of the senses, the illusion. When your brain processes, projects, 
paints, and materializes sensory input is NOT an illusion.. it when your 
brain does all that and is tricked into doing more. By definition, phantom

illusion of the brain.

an illusion.. then ok. All that our brain perceives is an illusion. That's 
what you say, but then you also say that even though that is the case, the 
world around us exists. That means the apple pie you smell (the "illusion") 
exists, the wall that you touch exists, the clouds that you see exists, the 
tea that you are tasting exists, the car horn that you are hearing exists.. 
everything you sense exists.. so color exists. It exists outside your 
brain, waiting to be processed internally just like everything else. It is 
a very real characteristic of reality.

top_comment.text:
People in the Himba tribe are able to detect the difference between two 
different blues that look identical to most westerners, but they cannot 
tell the difference between blue and green. In other words, their color 
boundaries are different. This seems to confirm that we see colors 
differently.

Our experiences are mapped to certain patterns in a neural network. If you 
fully understood your own brain as a network, and were able to do various 
experiments where you forced certain patterns to be stimulated in your 
brain, noting what the experience was like each time, eventually you might 
be able to develop an understanding for the relationship between the 
experience and the pattern, to the extent that you'd be able to imagine by 
analogy what sorts of experiences certain patterns would evoke, without 
having experienced them. At that point, you could study someone else's 
brain, and just from knowing all the details, be able to imagine what their 
experience is like, including color.﻿

comments.text:
+Ƹ̵̡Ӝ̵̨Ʒ I think it's one of the most interesting things ever. I'm studying 
linguistics and I've always been curious about the differences in ability 
of differentiating between colours depending on the native language.

For example, in my native language, Russian, there are two common words for 
the colour blue: "голубой" (light-blue) and "синий" (dark-blue). So every 
time I see something like "It's blue", I always have trouble picturing it, 
because just "blue" is too vague for me. It's the same with Italian and 
Mongolian.

In reverse, there are "purple" and "violet" for Russian one and only 
"фиолетовый". And up to this day I've never managed to find out the exact 
difference between them.

English language has "ginger" and "redhead" to describe someone's hair, in 
Russian there's only "рыжий"

Some of languages, for example, Vietnamese, Ancient Egyptian, do not 
differentiate between blue and green. There's even a linguistic term for it 
- "grue". As a result, the sky and grass are considered the same colour for 
them.

Chinese, Japanese and Korean have some really unclear concepts about the 
difference between green and blue and for that, the very definition of 
"green" and "blue" is pretty vague and you can see blue light on the 
traffic light.

Finnish has a separate colour between green and blue, something like teal.

In Chinese, red and pink are not separate colours but different shades.

Etc, etc.

comments.text:
Not at all. Think of specific colors with their own specific radiation 
signatures (wavelengths). Wavelengths are mathematical values set in stone. 
The argument is that each of us don't share the same mental picture of that 
wavelength. But you forget that we learned the same designation of specific 
wavelength in our infancy.

There are telescopes in orbit that are watching the sun. These telescopes 
are calibrated to observe the sun at differing wavelengths (x-ray, color 
spectrum, infrared, radio wave). They all see a different representation of 
the sun, but any astronomer looking at those pictures would still conclude 
they're staring at the sun. In this context, the difference in wavelengths 
is the nature of our brain wiring that process the optical signal and the 
astronomer is the brain center that creates the mental picture.

This video on qualia, current limitations of language, and theory of mind

Happy Wednesday, everybody!!

#ScienceEveryday﻿

comments.text:
Cool - we're on the same page then. The term "qualia", for me, simply 
evokes that particular conscious experience rather than the underlying 
neural processing itself - I certainly don't hold any weight for this 
experience being non-physical in any way; you can't have conscious 
experience / qualia without neural processing. 

Every non-physical proposal that I've seen has been inherently 
non-falsifiable and thus not really worthy of serious consideration. 

I also think that our technium is on track to engineer both artificial and 
biological neural circuits that produce conscious experiences, and later to 
gain mastery and produce novel conscious experiences. I do wonder if we'll 
be able to engineer novel colours, etc on either side of the conventional 
spectrum. And beyond the standard sensory modalities that we are currently 
hardwired for, states of consciousness that are physically impossible for 
us to presently imagine.
comments.author: Mark Bruce

be explained by language. When Mary escapes the room and actually 
experiences color (instead of just having the book smarts knowledge 
concerning wavelength of light etc.), there isn't anything magical about 
that... and we would expect to find Mary's brain adjusted accordingly. (now 
having the experience of color)

My opinion is that soon enough we will reverse engineer consciousness and 
actually be able to transmit experience directly. So, with the case of Mary 
and her Colorless Room, we will be able to give her knowledge of all the 
quantifiable (via language and mathematics) aspects of Color, and then also 
additionally transmit the experience of Color to her consciousness as well.

comments.text:
Sorry, but your comment is just incredibly wrong. A 650 nm wavelength of 
light is often referred to as "red".  I agree that no matter what, that 
corvette will be reflecting 650 nm wavelength to everyone, and everyone 
will call it "red".  However, the moment our eyes convert that 650 nm 
wavelength into electrical impulses, and our mind tries to interpret / 
process those electrical impulses, all similarity is thrown out the window. 
 No two brains are identical, like fingerprints, like trees, snowflakes, 
etc.. so those electrical impulses will travel different paths in our 
brains, and be interpreted differently for everyone. While the impulses 
created from a 650 nm wavelength of light will always travel the same paths 
in your mind to create what you know as "red" in your mind, for someone 
else that 650 nm wavelength of light can and will travel a different path 
in their mind, and create what you know as "blue", but they know it as 
"red".  You will both be experiencing different colors, but both referring 
to the same wavelength.

top_comment.text:
Oh hey, an explanation of the word "qualia" that doesn't translate 
immediately to "magic pixie dust".  Cool.

It also suggests (via analogy to AI) how we could assess the actual values 
of qualia in our experience: if we could brain-map two different people's 
idea of "red", we could recognise whether they were actually different.  
This would require neurology and instrumentation beyond our current 
capabilities, but it is very easy to see how it could be possible: if our 
subjective visual processing attaches to a fixed set of connections in a 
fixed order, it would in theory be easy to identify that someone's "red 
pathways" look a lot more like my "green pathways" than my red ones.﻿

I created an embarrassing and weird phrase when I'm about to go to sleep 
and feel VERY different from when I was out and about in the day....when 
I'm about to feel the change, I think (or sometimes say out loud) "Oh no, 
I'm entering the darkness!" because when I'm awake, I'm really hyper and I 
VERY rarely feel negative emotions like anger or sadness. Even if someone's 
annoying me, I just laugh it out or if it gets on my nerves, I forget about 
it after 5-10 seconds and I start smiling again like some idiot, even if 
someone were to punch me across the face, I'd get probably angry and hit 
the person back, but I would never hold a grudge against that person, but 
very often at night when I'm at bed, my mood changes, I start to regret and 
almost scream at the embarrassing things I did that day (if there were any) 
and start to feel depressed and nervous about stuff like "What am I gonna 
do in the future? I'm not good enough to graduate school" or "I'm not good 
and responsible enough to start a family or take care of the family I have 
at the moment". Basically all the emotions that I have not (or rarely) felt 
in the time I was awake comes flooding down. Mostly negative emotions. 
There are less often times where my brain goes to overdrive or something 
and suddenly, I feel like my Japanese is more fluent and I remember a whole 
lot of things that I've forgotten a long time ago, lessons from class would 
start coming back to me and I would start wondering about the weird things 
in the universe like "Who made us?" and stuff like that. There are rare 
chances of me entering that "mode" when I'm up and about. Sometimes my mind 
goes blank for a second and I just stare at something then all those 
emotions come flooding in my head. Is this some sort of illness? I feel

mistakenly  green (i.e. the color of healthy grass).﻿

which is slightly darker than your average maraschino cherry. They both say 
the same thing; and that is that the apple is red. However, if one person 
perceives the apple as red as you may know it, but the other person sees it 
as a different color entirely, perhaps blue, how would they discover the 
variation in perception? Due to education and common knowledge, these 
people have both come to know the color red as whatever they perceive it 
as, but there would be no way to fully realize what either person sees, and 
you would only ever realize their difference in perception through 
comparisons of other hues and colors.

comments.text:
+Daniel Muriungi
It's pointless to argue if label X is better than label Y when both are 
absolutely arbitrary in the first place.
Your example is when people can't agree on using the same label for the 
same thing. This indeed can cause problems, but that's not the topic.
The reason why different things get different labels is because they 
are...well..different, distinguishable.  If two things are 
indistinguishable (on whatever level) they won't get a different label, no 
matter what label in specific (assuming some will for consistency).
The point is that everyone will see the exact same strawberry with the 
exact same physical properties and it doesn't matter what these physical 
properties cause in the observers brain. Observers will agree for a label 
to describe the objects properties which effects they all can perceive. In 
the end, it doesn't fucking matter how you call it.
The only way to get around this, is to claim that the strawberry has indeed 
different physical properties depending on the observer that is observing 
the strawberry and that gets you straight into an absurd solipsist position 
that is absolutely insane..
comments.author: Asto

top_comment.author: Pri Mary

comments.text: Watch the video again. You completely missed the point.
comments.author: Jesus Chan

comments.text:
+The Starhawk101-Minecraft Gamer yes but that's irrelevant. Let's say,
PERSON A is "normal" and sees "normal" colours
PERSON B is "colourblind"

FOR EXAMPLE, Red = <x>hz

PERSON B goes to preschool and sees a crayon with the <x>hz wavelength, 
which has to be "red", even though B sees it as a sick green-blue colour.

PERSON B asks a teacher, "what colour is this?"

TEACHER has "normal" vision, so he says "it's RED"

10 years later, PERSON A lays out a set of crayons for PERSON B and asks 
"point to the red crayon"

PERSON B will then point to the crayon that has the colour of the <x>hz 
wavelength, which is the red crayon, even though in B's mind, it looks like 
a sickly green-blue.

IF PERSON A knew about the inconsistency between the minds of PERSON B and 
himself, he would think that PERSON B was pointing at a "green-blue" 
colour. Which he doesn't. All PERSON A knows is that B did point at the red 
crayon, so this test is completely worthless.

If your teacher taught you that the colour "RED" was called "BLUE", then 
your test would  work. But that has nothing to do with your eyes, that 
would be your teacher having not been taught properly. At the end of the 
day, it doesn't matter how we see colours. It doesn't matter that you and I 
do not see the same "red". What counts is that we all have the same words 
for the same colours, because then we'd have a common ground to agree on.
comments.author: Jesus Chan

comments.text:
It wouldn't work. It's not a matter of what we are taught, but how we 
interpret this color information. Yes, we are taught that "X thing is Y 
colored", and thus we will point the same object as everyone when asked 
"What is Y-colored?", but what makes you think the Y color you see looks 
the same to me? Imagine I don't have any problem seeing any color, but I do 
see what you know as red, as what you know as blue, and the same vice 
versa: we both know it by the same name, but see totally the opposite.
comments.author: José  Villagrán

comments.text:
+TheTrooper9169666   That is indeed why art exists, but for many people 
their ability to craft and create is limited by a disconnect between the 
mind's eye and the hands.  I believe that everyone is capable of imagining 
universal scale masterpieces of motion and fantastic form.  That with just 
a spark of creativity any and all things created by even the most talented 
of artists would be put to shame by the immeasurable scale and supreme 
detail of our minds.  I'm a graphic artist, it's the closest thing I'll 
ever be to a sculptor or a painter, 3d modeling and computer generated 
illusions, digital smoke and mirrors. 

Even on my best days I can't get anywhere close to what I really want to 
create, but I'm no artist at all, an artiste perhaps from time to time.  
Like being trapped inside of your own grand imagination, something I bet 
the vast majority of people experience.

Though I do have one artistic talent in the form of words, but writing as 
art is unforgiving and when it becomes a chore there's no fun there 
anymore.  After proofreading I realize I rhymed and alliterated 
unintentionally so there's a bit of art.  While typing might not be the 
fastest form of artistic expression(a picture is worth a thousand words), 
it's at least something that with practice can be learned by anyone, it's 
up to them to choose to use it to it's fullest at that point.  Flighty 4 AM 
thoughts.

Just glad that Youtube lets us talk in more than 260 characters these days.

top_comment.text:
Hi all.

I want to spend some time to talk to you about what UX designers are often 
most obsessed with: perception of experience. The act of 'feeling' 
abstractly. 
UX designers face the challenge to try and guess how other people, with 
different minds, experience an interactive product. It is more or less the 
same problem that every designer or artist that have to deliver any kind of 
information to an 'user' or an 'audience' have to deal with every day. 

How can we craft amazing experiences when experiences and feelings are 
often very difficult to communicate and - actually - seems like there is no 
way to prove that 2 people experience the world in the exact same way?

Check out this genius video about this topic (is very enjoyable, and not 
boring at all… or is it?)﻿
top_comment.author: Alessandro Filippi

+mai_styles If you think about it further, a color of an object is the 
remaining waves of the light, which the object did not absorb. For example 
if you paint something truly red, then it will absorb red from white light 
and it will reflect anything else, leaving a greenish light and you will 
percieve the object as green or torquise (the complement of the red). Is 
your mind blown already? :)

comments.text:
+MrTheKingOfLoquendo No it is not normal for everyone, though it is 
common.  I have never once had a black and white dream.  I find the concept 
baffling, and so I always ask people if they dream in colour or in black 
and white.  Most people answer that they dream in black and white, or that 
they do not remember their dreams, or that it varies, and many say that 
they do not know if they dream in colour or in black and white.  So far, no 
one has told me that they have vivid, detailed, lucid, insightful and 
colourful dreams all the time, as I do, though I am sure that there are 
those who do as well.
comments.author: Agnieszka Maria

comments.text:
Those I've known, who have been blind for all or most of their lives, do 
not dream in images.  Their dreams are experienced with the same senses 
that they use in waking life.  For example, one blind friend told me of a 
dream of being on a plane, and described it in all detail except for visual 
information, for which he had no frame of reference.

comments.text:
Pretty much regardless of whether you are deaf or blind (from birth), their 
sensual experiences within dreams will mirror their sensual experience when 
awake (aside from the weirdness and surrealism and sudden shifts that are 
typical of dreams). If they have never heard sound or seen images, they 
will not experience such within their dreams.

A person who was blind from death will draw upon his other senses in dreams 
(hearing, touch, smell, etc.) just as they experience them awake.

If you swap blue with red, there's nothing saying the person wouldn't also 
consider the spectrum to flow naturally.  Think of it like a monitor. 
 Rather than each pixel outputting red, green, and blue, it would output 
blue, green, and red.  The solid blues and reds would be swapped, sure, but 
so also would the gradient colors like yellow.  Yellow would appear to be 
cyan to them and vice versa.  Magenta would remain the same.  So, in 
actuality, the color spectrum would flow to a person with swapped colors 
exactly as well as one with "normal" ones.

comments.text:
One of the best *travel* into theory of mind I've ever made is the one lead 
by Oliver Sacks in his *An Anthropologist On Mars*. Among others 
breathtaking stories he tells in this book, the one of this painter – who 
were once able to recognize with sharp precision every single color on the 
pantone scale, but then loose this ability and become blind to color but 
not to light frequency – deserve all our attention.

I think that if we can measure a certain shade of red and point out the 
frequency of light it produces we can also catalogue it into a diagram – 
such as RGB, or HBS – and release the matter of "qualia" to a semantic 
problem.

What is then actually interesting is that colors often have the same 
meaning in different culture – e. g. male-white and female-black.

By the way: I dare you to guess the color of the guy's shirt in the video!

comments.author: bryan weaver

comments.text:
+Kristin M This requires really abstract thought. When your brain generates 
it's very first image from the optical nerves, you see whatever you see, 
from your brain translating a complex string of electrical impulses, into 
more electrical impulses that are thoughts, based on who knows what 
criteria. If those criteria were set in stone, a blind person would know 
what red was, even without having seen it. You continue to see whatever it 
is that you see until one day someone says, and you're able to understand, 
that object is red. From that point onward, that wavelength of light, is 
now called red. Two different people who have gone through this process 
will both identify that wavelength of light as red, but they may see it in 
their mind differently. If the way they react to the color is the same, 
this can be a learned experience. If say what they perceive as red is 
actually a different color, as they go through life, they will experience 
things that associate that color with hotness, being spicy, exciting, etc. 
So for all intents and purposes when they look at that color they see the 
same thing, and they're both identifying the same wavelength, but inside 
their minds, the color could be different.
comments.author: hzuiel

comments.text:
+Kristin M There are no innate "triggers" between colors and the brain.  If 
you have any they were formed through your lifetime, you were not made that 
way.  Colors are interpreted by our brains via information it receives from 
our retinas.  If somebody has a different ratio of rods to cones than 
another person their brain will be receiving different information and 
translating it to be slightly different.

+NOSfusion I agree that the association of the colour red with blood likely 
affects our feeling about the colour.  But blood is also not only 
associated with death or being hurt.  On the flip side blood, with its

some cultures.  It is also the colour of fire, which in ancient times is 
what gives you food and protection from wild animals and the cold 
environment.  By that logic I can also argue that it would be a "primal 
instinct" to associate red with youth and new life.  My point is, we cannot 
just look at the customs of the Western cultures and generalize it to 
assume that it is basic instincts of the entire human species.

If I am understanding your use of the word "triggering" correctly, as in it 
instill feeling of tension, anger, or feeling of being threatened in our 
mind, then no, it doesn't have the same triggering effects for everyone. 
 In the Eastern cultures the colour red is not associated with danger, but 
rather with happiness and life.  That is why in traditional Chinese culture 
the groom and bride wears red, whereas the white coloured prominent in a 
Western wedding would be better suited for a funeral due to the colour's 
association with death.  The reason the colour red evokes certain feelings 
in a person is mostly cultural I think.  As children we are taught that 
when the perception of colour produced by that certain range of wavelengths 
is called "red", and is associated with danger/happiness depending what 
your culture is.

top_comment.text:
Not all experts who study perception believe what Michael has claimed here. 
Michael is a constructivist. Some experts on perception believe that 
perception is direct. They would argue that we can see red because it is 
out there in the world. If Michael's constructivist theory is true, it 
would mean that everything you have ever felt, tasted, or heard was also 
all in your head. I think Michael is wrong about that.﻿
top_comment.author: Tom Bombadil

comments.text:
I think that we need the right kind of sensory organs to detect color and 
that differences in sensory organs from one person to the next can result 
in picking up different kinds of color information from our surroundings. 
Michael isn't arguing that different eyes and different brains tune into, 
or pick up, different kinds of information from the environment. His claim 
is that have no experience of the world. But an explanation of seeing where 
nothing is seen is not an explanation of seeing. 

Michael's claim is also massively inadequate when the entirety of life on 
our planet is taken into account. Species, from bacteria to humans, have 
ways of detecting information from their environment and responding to that 
information. Is Michael is willing to claim that inside the minds of 
bacteria are constructed representations of their environment? If he won't 
do that, I wonder where he draws the line. What species for Michael can see 
things as they are and which ones have to construct images in their minds? 
And why would we have evolved a construct images in our minds when we, or 
our evolutionary ancestors, were already seeing what was out there? It does 
not make sense to take a method for perceiving the world and replace it 
with one where we cannot perceive the world, but have to rely on an 
inferior copy that we construct in our minds.
comments.author: Tom Bombadil

comments.text: Love your name btw
comments.author: MrEffinBest

comments.text:
That is very interesting and I believe partially true. I think what Michael 
is trying to represent in his video though isn't that the perception of say 
"red" exists to all whom perceive it, but that there is a variability in 
what that "red" can be to each individual. The simple fact is that we are 
both physiologically and psychologically able to perceive colors. This is 
most likely due to adaptations developed over millions of years to fulfill 
some need, primarily feeding and avoiding dangerous plants and animals. 
However if you come from a completely different perspective as a separate 
being from all the lifeforms on planet earth and then try and describe what 
color is you cannot know that trees aren't actually purple, or that the sky 
is yellow. Yes, red is out there in the world.... to us. It is 
constructivist, but logical.

And indeed everything you have ever felt, tasted, or heard all did happen 
in your head. It doesn't mean that those things aren't real or experienced 
similarly by many different people. It just means the equipment you used to 
experience it is also similar, or identical which is the whole point of DNA 
and genetics, yes? We are basically an intricate, biological machine if you 
break it down.

top_comment.text:
Saying our reds can be different is meaningless when we can never know that 
difference, if it existed. Also, saying our reds can be different would 
also be stating our genetics can different, well, they can, to a degree. 
The remaining question is how much difference, if any, can there be to our 
vision due to slightly different genetics? Can there be slightly different 
genes to slide the difference in perception of light wavelengths one way or 
another when it comes to our eyes and brain perception of signals from 
them? In that case, I imagine there can be slight difference in perceived 
colors, but a red is still a long wavelength of light and a blue still a 
shorter wavelength of light. Relative to another, colors will still produce 
a linear difference, one from the other, a red will still only affect the 
cones of the eye which respond to longer wavelengths, blue to the ones 
which respond to shorter. I guess from there it's all perception baby and 
we know we perceive things differently, but when it comes to something so 
basic and hard wired into us from our genes which are probably so close as 
not to make much difference in this area, I think we are probably seeing 
the same red. From here it becomes a philosophical discussion, I guess, 
except for one good example, individuals who are color blind, this is an 
example of extreme genetic difference when it comes to our eyes, they do 
see color differently, except not different from one to the other, rather, 
unable to see the difference.﻿

+jimbobsports The properties of light entering your eye is not affected by 
the length of which it has traveled. Why the sky at day appears blue is 
well understood and has to do with light refraction, not infinite distance. 
The sky at night appears black because there is so little light coming from 
(or threw) the sky (compared to from elsewhere), not infinity. 

My basic point being; there is no way to determine how far a single 
light-ray has traveled just by "seeing" it.

comments.text:
That's generally impossible.
Having color blindness is a genetic mutation that leaves out certain rods 
in your eyes.  People that have normal vision have all these rods, while 
people with color blindness do not.  So, you either have all of them or you 
don't.  Therefor making a clear defining line between being color blind and 
having normal vision.

understanding on how people see colour. There are people with synaesthesia 
where their senses mix and they can experience for example colour as sound 
or even taste. Then there is the case of colours that do not exist and our 
brain creates them like pink. Colour is a physical phenomena and 
measurable. Even if the concept of colour perception being different for 
each human is correct, how could the colours perceived be different and the 
psychological effects of colours be very similar across humans? What about 
the perception of colour across other species? Look at how many plants and 
animals generate specific colours to give information to other species. If 
colour could be perceived so different across the majority of humans, how 
comes across groups, civilizations and time the perception of such colour 
is the same?

  I don't disagree that perception  is something generated in the mind, but 
for most humans it must be the same. Brains work the same, so do eyes. 
There are cases where tribes have developed extreme descriptions about 
colour because of their environment. Look at the tribes that live close to 
the north pole, they have multiple names to describe snow, based not just 
on texture, but on colour, etc. Then there is the case that if you take 
some coloured lens and use it for a long period of time you will dream on 
this colour. This discussion is like saying that someone would be taught 
that red is blue then their perception of red would be blue which is 
clearly a language issue rather than a perception issue. You could even go 
as far to say that this could be said about many if not all of the things 
we perceive  For sure there are people out there that the perception of x 
or y colour is different, but overall I would say that it is very similar 
across the board.

Given that my own eyes don't both even perceive color exactly the same, I 
cant imagine that everyone would see color exactly the same.

To be clear, my right eye sees slightly bluer and my left sees slightly 
yellower. It is very subtle, but if I close one eye and then the other, 
everything looks a slight bit different in each eye. I also tend to 
perceive things as grey that other people seem to perceive as a very pale 
green. I am not sure if this means I have a subtle form of color blindness 
or not, but I can say for sure that I have no issue passing color blindness 
tests, and I create colorful art that is never described as having strange 
or inaccurate color, yet I definitely perceive color differently than 
others.

 ﻿
top_comment.author: TheOriginalGinger213

comments.text:
+TheOriginalGinger213
I also have an astigmatism and am nearsighted and this does play a role in 
the way that our eyes perceive color. Since color is in fact not tangible 
or real, it is a wavelength emitted by an electromagnetic field that is 
perceived differently through the way the eye perceives the wavelength. So 
because of our mutual astigmatism our eyes are shaped differently than the 
average "normal" persons eye. Due to this irregularity in shape the 
wavelengths are interpreted differently by each eye thus giving a different 
hue, or shade, to certain colors given off by the visual light spectrum.

All that being said having an astigmatism isn't the only thing, other than 
colorblindness, that affects the perception of color. Any shape 
irregularity having to do with your eye will alter your perception of color 
as it's a wavelength that is registered through rods and cones and many 
other anatomical devices which means that shape irregularity in your eye 
alters how it is reflected and refracted as you perceive it to alter the 
wavelength that you are seeing.

I hope that makes sense, if not I'd be more than happy to explain a 
different way that might help you to understand if you are curious. I hope 
this helps in explaining why you see a difference in color with each 
individual eye. Also feel free to ask if you want an explanation as to why, 
when you look at a color with both eyes, it is not altered in a blueish or 
yellowish hue. The human body is an amazing thing in how it works. Hope 
this helps! :D

comments.text:
That could be because the light source is not directly even when it hits 
your eyes, or that the dominant side of your body reacts faster.

In either case, the difference in contraction of your pupils and color of 
the light entering each causes that differentiation in shading. It's the 
same as walking from a bright space into a dark space and how colors change 
as your eyes adjust.

We all are composed of the same chemical neurological networks, so while 
there may be slight variations in how we see color, it's pretty safe to 
assume we're not seeing radically different things unless we have a 
deficiency or physical variation that would affect the result.

This video is confusing interpretation with mechanical function. Color is 
not interpreted, it's chemically produced.

comments.text:
You are confusing light with hue. If foreground and background are equally  
but not fully light or dark AND the same hue, it would make it hard to see. 
However at full brightness or darkness, it would be impossible to 
distinguish hue no matter how different. White is full lightness as black 
is no lightness , white itself is not a color. So even if we perceive 
colors differently, it fundamentally will always stand out.


In other words white is when your photo receptors are equally stimulated, 
black is when they are not stimulated at all. Color is the result of an 
imbalance of stimulation, so with the same background brightness, white 
will always appear brighter than any given color, because more receptors 
are stimulated. So white will always stand out more than any color.
comments.author: nustada

comments.text:
Think about it this way.

The photo receptors in your eye responds to the absorption of light of 
certain wavelengths. But suppose for a moment that on average yours are 
tuned to say 495 nm to 570 nm for "green" while mine are tuned to 497 nm to 
572 nm.

We'd both look at a green object and accept it as green, but my green would 
be less blue and more red than yours.

Now factor in variations in the enormous amounts of photo receptors in each 
eye. Now you end up with an uneven a distribution of wavelength 
sensitivity, where maybe you have a slight lack of sensitivity in the 521 
to 531 nm range, and is over sensitive in the 553 to 559 nm range, and that 
"heat map" will differ from human to human. It would even differ from eye 
to eye, and probably during your lifetime as well, as your cells die and 
are replaced.

Suppose you now looked at an object that emits light at exactly 525 nm. You 
do this several times during your lifetime. But during that life time your 
eyes have changed slightly, so one year it was more sensitive to that 
wavelength and the next year it was less sensitive. It'd still be the same 
wavelength, but your brain would be getting a different signal.

And that's where it gets interesting, because you "know" that it's supposed 
to be that specific colour. So you essentially trick yourself into thinking 
that it's the same colour experience, when in fact your eyes told you 
something slightly different.

comments.text:
My red will never be the same as your red.

My first visual instinct on the third rubik's cube color in the video was 
"red". It switched over to a greenish-purplish gray as soon as Michael 
mentioned that it was green. And then the cube's side started to alternate 
between various saturations of greenish-purplish gray and purplish-greenish 
gray, roughly in the frequency your perception might switch between duck 
and rabbit in this image: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Duck-Rabbit_illusion.jpg

Okay, I was on a sunny balcony with my laptop, therefore the contrast of my 
screen and the video went below "watchable without concentrating on 
perceiving the image", which always makes it harder for me to distinguish 
between red and green. As soon as the light on my laptop screen was better 
(i.e. I went inside), I could clearly identify the green face of the 
rubik's cube as being green.

You know, at dawn, when your color perception gradually improves as the day 
lights up? What are the last two colors you are not able to distinguish? I 
always find that red and green are the last two colors to pop out from the 
greenish-purplish gray scale of undecidedness into my personal visual 
spectrum.

equipment' look at the same thing, they both see the same thing. (As long 
as we talk about basic stuff like colors where subjective bias finds no 
reason to apply.) Of course, empirically this is unprovable, but it can be 
derived logically from empiric evidence.
In short: Red looks the same for everybody because that which observes is 
not an individual, but the unified consciousness. There is only one 
observer, thus there cannot be deviations in conscious experience. While 
the perspective, the viewpoint, is subjective, the nature of consciousness 
cannot be altered.
This is tough stuff for narrow-minded scientists (because mindblowing), but 
in Eastern spiritual sciences, it is nothing new.

comments.text:
+L2K4D44L4R hi there, I think you're slightly mistaken if you check the 
Encyclopedia of philosophy it definitely states that "Locke appears to have 
been the first to formulate explicitly an inverted spectrum scenario" ... I 
think what you're referencing to when quoting Democritus and the 
fascinating points he made is more to do with another very interesting 
philosophical inquiry called the "primary versus secondary quality 
distinction" which Locke and many others have worked on but originates from 
Democritus(amazing feat given the time he lived in)...

Locke also put forward some idea's on the primary versus secondary quality 
distinction that you were pointing out but he would conclude that it 
contradicts the last line of your second paragraph, Locke stated that we 
define an object by its primary and secondary qualities. He takes heat as 
an example of a secondary quality. If you put one hand in a bucket of cold 
water, and the other hand in a bucket of warm water, then put both hands in 
a bucket of lukewarm water, one of your hands is going to tell you that the 
water is cold and the other that the water is hot. Locke says that since 
two different objects (both your hands) perceive the water to be hot and 
cold, then the heat is not a primary quality of the water and rather a 
secondary quality of perception. Instead of two hands you could of course 
expand the idea to two people disagreeing about the water being hot or 
cold...  

The biggest problem I had with the Vsauce video (and I am a fan) is that he 
badly misrepresented Dan Dennetts position which is one I find the most 
persuasive ... Dan explicitly rejects the use of the term Qualia on the 
grounds that at best its incoherent and worse it's actually causing a 
profound amount of confusion ... he even goes so far as to reject the 
medium in which qualia are supposed to be taking place If there is no such 
medium, there is no fact of the matter about whether one's qualia (as 
distinguished to one's merely reactive dispositions) are inverted.. 

I would like draw your attention to the last sentences of your piece ", 
Russian differentiates between sky blue and darker blue, using two distinct 
words for two colors that we (can) call by the same word. This still does 
not mean that a Russian sees the color of the sky in any other way than I 
do." ... This is all about fascinating and ferociously debated subject of 
linguistic relativity and the color naming debate, You should check out 
this documentary :

http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x1kabkn_bbc-horizon-2011-do-you-see-what-i-see-pdtv-xvid_tech 
  
skip forward to 45:30 and check out the piece on the muwabi tribe
there is actually some very interesting empirical evidence that may suggest 
that the language structures we use to understand the world actually have a 
profound effect on the way we perceive the world.... I was very very 
surprised when I first stumbled across this information.. I honestly don't 
know what to think anymore except that I find it incredibly difficult to 
think about the mind and conscious experience, I also find myself pulled 
more towards the methods of thinking and the theories of mind from people 
like Dennett, Metzinger, Sapolski ... the more I try to understand this 
stuff the more confused I become.... thank you for your repy
