comments.text:
+Erick Murphy You're actually placing the appearance of this idea a couple 
of thousand years too late. See Stanford's Encyclopedia of Philosophy: 
"[Democritus] famously denies that perceptible qualities other than shape 
and size (and, perhaps, weight) really exist in the atoms themselves: one 
direct quotation surviving from Democritus claims that ‘by convention sweet 
and by convention bitter, by convention hot, by convention cold, by 
convention color; but in reality atoms and void’".

The example in the video of the green strawberry is misleading, and the 
whole treatment of the video of this interesting philosophical question is 
a bit shallow. Democritus couldn't have known it: colour is the mental 
correlate of a physical fact. Of course I can find out if you see a similar 
colour, which we call "red", as I do when looking at a ripe strawberry. The 
sensations and connotations that come with a colour are another matter. But 
it is not possible that what to me is green is red to you and that at the 
same time what to me is red is blue to you, and that what to me is blue is 
orange to you. Not anymore at least than it is possible that what is hot to 
me is cold to you.

Disabilities aside, it is of course natural that all humans (and all 
members of the same species in general) roughly agree on their assessments 
of physical facts because the correct assessment of those facts enables 
individuals to survive. One of those facts is the wavelength of the light 
reflected by objects.

Nevertheless, the colour spectrum may be compartmentalised differently in 
different cultures. Without speaking the language I've been told that, for 
example, Russian differentiates between sky blue and darker blue, using two 
distinct words for two colours that we (can) call by the same word. This 
still does not mean that a Russian sees the colour of the sky in any other 
way than I do.

comments.text:
+AdversaryOmega
"If I close my eyes, I can imagine colors or degrees of brightness I've 
never seen before, I can imagine shapes I've never seen before. I can 
imagine things that I have to see exist."
Only within a very limited range. Our creativity and imagination is *always* 
bound to what we have so far experienced. A person that was born blind 
simply has no concept of color, they can't imagine it and no amount of 
explaining or imagination-training will change that.
As an example: imagine a simple key... any key. And now imagine a similar 
key for a 5-dimensional lock. You cannot do it. That's are so far removed 
from our personal world view, from our experience, that we don't even know 
where to begin. Two more orthogonal dimensions? ... WHERE?!

"Sound in it self is a pressure wave" "I'm am fully aware and have a vast 
understanding of sound. I'm beyond debate and opinion."
No, you aren't. You're mixing up sensation and perception. Sound is what 
our brains make of the vibrations that are picked up by our ears. Just like 
color is what our brains make of the electromagnetic waves picked up by our 
eyes.
Sensation and perception are two different things, the vibrations are 
measurable, objective, always there - but sound is our brain's personal 
interpretation of those vibrations and so very subjective and dependant on 
the listener.

Un truc intéressant reliée, j'avais écouter un video sur ce sujet, mais je 
ne le retrouve pas. 
En gros il y a un phénomème neurologique (synesthesia) qui fait que la 
personne associe une couleur a des nombres. Une personne qui a ce phénomène 
est aussi daltonienne et elle dit voir des couleurs martiennes lorsqu'on 
lui présente certains nombres.

Ça ne prouve rien pour savoir si on voit les mêmes couleurs, mais sa 
démontre que les couleurs sont "hard-coded" dans notre cerveau.

A color is a sensation in your mind that makes things seem familiar. A 
color could be unique to us, but we wont ever know. For instance, imagine a 
color (im obviously speaking to people that can see color while doing this) 
that is dark. It looks as though it would be cold when you touch it. It 
seems to somehow have the lightest and the darkest colors mixed within it. 
The surface of it (if applied correctly) would reflect the light coming 
from the ceiling. A small, perfect white rectangle that spreads it's way 
throughout the surface. The color it's self in recap is (forgot to add 
this) ashy. It is a perfect mix of the darkest, and lightest possible 
color. It would reflect the light perfectly on it's surface, and give the 
color a glow. It seems cold to the touch.

Got it?

It's grey. Yeah, kinda exciting of an explanation for such a dull colour, 
but it's the best i could do.

I have wondered this too. Wouldn't it be interesting if everyone's favorite 
color was the same? Of course he mentions something at the beginning "that 
color isn't real..like protons and.." of course this leaves a possible 
logical fallacy.
Namely that if our perceptions are not real(eg color), we cannot use them 
to conclude that protons ARE real --nor that anything is real and therefore 
it may be safe to conclude that nothing matters - except for then there is 
Pascal's wager (with the assumption that we think, therefore we exist) - 
though really everything comes down to faith and what we decide 
(perceivable or not) that we believe.
 
Anyway, got overly enthusiast in replying... fun to ponder, just for the 
sake of enjoying it, maybe it is a theory of mind thing :)

comments.text:
+Muhammad Nawaz Aslam  This man gets it.    In a scientific sense, all two 
individuals can agree on is that they are sensing the frequency of light 
generally referred to as red.    Experience can not be directly shared.     
Even if we reach the point where we can use brain scanners and electrodes 
to "share" an experience, all you can accurately say is that you are 
experiencing electronic signals from a machine which originated in another 
person's brain in response to viewing the frequency of light generally 
referred to as red.

This may seem like pointless semantics, but it really isn't.   It's 
important to keep your language as accurate as possible so as to avoid 
falling into logic traps.

comments.text:
+Mahmoud Qahawish No, this video truly is awful.
1. Color is interpreted by signals received by the photoreceptors in your 
eyes. The video was wrong in this respect.
2. Barring abnormalities, all photoreceptors will output the same signal 
given the same initial stimulus.
3. Brain architecture is relatively uniform.

Basically, there is no reason to suspect that different people perceive the 
same color in different ways. Obviously there are a few exceptions due to 
the nature of life, but by and large everyone sees red in the same way.

And while I'm on my soapbox, humans discovered math. They did not invent 
it. Our notation for it is fabricated, but if we ever found a spacefaring 
alien species, they'd know probably know calculus. They wouldn't use f'(x) 
or d/dx, but that doesn't change the fact that they're still doing calculus.

comments.text:
+breezebro It's even worse than that. All our ideas are just abstractions 
and abstractions always omit the details.

For example, "male" and "female" are concepts we think of as perfectly 
binary, but in practice even physically it's more of a spectrum that just 
tends to cluster around the two extremes (even the XX/XY distinction isn't 
perfect -- e.g. there can be more than one "X" but the child will only 
develop as a male if "his" SRY gene is functional).

Another example is: we don't actually speak the same language. Every person 
has their own "ideolect", which is generally based on those of the people 
around us (i.e. parents or people we grew up with, but also those we 
interact with as adults) and it is constantly changing until we die. What's 
worse, we also have various different subsets we use depending on who we 
talk to or even how we feel. It's not surprising machines are bad at 
understanding us -- it's far more amazing other humans do.

We like to think that we are all "born equal", but this is actually not 
true in the direct sense: every single person is different (and in fact, 
each person is different at any given moment, right down to the cells they 
are made of). The idea isn't that we are actually all the same -- it just 
means we should all enjoy the same rights irrespective of where we come 
from.

It's easy to wonder what the point of abstractions is if they are so 
obviously broken, but it's simply a consequence of how our brains work. In 
order to be able to reason about the real world at all, we need to be able 
to compare situations, objects and persons to other scenarios we have 
experienced before. And to make them comparable we need to reduce them to 
their common denominator leaving us with mere abstractions. If we wouldn't 
do this, we could only perceive but never reflect or act upon those 
perceptions.

Oh, and this is also where stereotypes, superstitions and prejudices come 
from. We are not only wired to group our experiences, we're also wired to 
detect causal relationships (even where there are none) and agency (even 
when things are not caused by any living being). In a lot of ways we're 
just like B. F. Skinner's pigeons doing silly dances because we think 
they're making a difference.
comments.author: Alan Plum

comments.text:
Picky eater? I reckon a large part of this is due to how you were 
introduced to food as a child. If you are encouraged to try lots of new 
foods as a child, I think you are given a wide variety of things you like, 
so the chances are that if you come across something new then it won't be 
too outside your comfort zone, and you can tolerate it to the point of 
eventually liking it. If you were not exposed to many types of food as a 
child, then your 'acceptable range' of flavours is quite narrow, and then 
later in life you will end up with lots of things that are well outside 
your comfort zone, and it will take a lot more effort to like them.

From my experience, you don't always like something the first time you try 
it; and sometimes you actually have to work quite hard to try and feel the 
benefit of eating it! But once you are over that, the food can become 
tasty. This means that without that ability to try and like something 
outside of your comfort zone of eating, you will have a small palate of the 
things you like. If you really go for it, I believe you can like almost any 
food.

This state of mind must also help to some extent. If you are open to try 
lots of new foods, then you will slowly chip away at your flavour comfort 
boundary, increasing your comfort zone. If not, then you will just stay in 
your edible comfort zone forever. It makes sense that this would require 
effort, as there is probably an evolutionary advantage to only continue to 
eat the food you already like. By doing this, you don't put your body at 
risk of eating something that could kill you; if you have already eaten it, 
then it is probably safe!

It would be amazing to raise a child on all the different foods of the 
world to see what they will enjoy and dislike later in life.

Feel free to call bullshit on any of this. It's just what I have come to 
reckon.
comments.author: radash

comments.text:
Our cones (elements that see colours) react to specific frequencies, and 
the blue and red do not overlap (or at least I believe they don't). Mixing 
the two creates complicated things inside the brain, where the brain 
assumes that the signals means another colour. The same goes for yellow; +Christie 
Nel is spot on, we do not have any yellow cones. Yellow is 'seen' as a mix 
of two other cones, green and red. Red does overlap with green, but not 
with blue, creating complicated things. Now even more funny, imagine this 
(and this does happen to me, somewhat). A computer screen never actually 
outputs yellow. Now imagine what someone who does see yellow would see? You 
can't see yellow, but you do. He can see yellow, but he doesn't. Optics are 
fascinating...
comments.author: James A. Langbridge

comments.text:
Actually, we can't see yellow.  Our brain makes the assumption that a 
thing's colour has a distribution.  So if it contains some red and some 
green, our brain assumes that its dominant frequency has to be in between, 
i.e. yellow.  So if you had a light with a notch filter that filtered out 
all colour except yellow, you couldn't see it.  Here's a better question... 
why does mixing red and blue make a colour that looks like violet?  Violet 
is a true colour with a single frequency, but purple does not.  And screens 
can't display violet.
comments.author: Christie Nel

comments.text:
Interesting comments. I think we can't teach robots *feel* the colors 
unless we'll know how *we* feel the colours. We don't understand our brain.
PS: Why do we see yellow when we mix green and red? Yellow has it's own 
frequency!
comments.author: Michal Grňo

comments.text:
I had a very talented blind friend who was a musical genius.  It was very 
interesting to go on walks with him in the mountains and talk about 
colours.  Blind people are some of the happiest people I know.  I think if 
I had to explain colour, I'd say it's like touching a surface that has 
three different textures, but with the same intensity, say horizontal 
ridges, vertical and diagonal.  Except with colour one's brain generates 
another three extra virtual colours when you have combinations (magenta, 
yellow and cyan, so it looks like 6 colours).  So imagine if you could see 
the feelings of textures on top of the intensity you already see.
comments.author: Christie Nel

comments.text:
Since what I see is essentially light intensity, that is an excellent 
comparison. Teachers showed me a card, and said "This is red", so I thought 
that red is this really dark colour that looks a lot like black. And that 
is essentially it; I do make mistakes, but it all boils down to 
interpretation. Somebody said what they saw, and I tried to learn that. I 
couldn't understand why someone said "This is green", and then took another 
card and said "This is yellow". But they are the same! Why didn't you call 
the first one yellow, then! That simple sentence got me sent to the 
doctors, and then a specialist, and then changed my life. To this day, I 
still do not know what red is, because I can't see it. I also can't see 
traffic lights or braking lights, so I walk everywhere. Not seeing colours 
can be a huge problem...

comments.author: Joshua Jansen

comments.text:
Our eyes simply convert different wavelengths of light into electrical 
impulses.  How our brains interpret those electrical impulses to create the 
images we "see" is different for everybody.  We don't actually "see" the 
world how it truly is, we "see" an opinion created by our minds.  So you 
are wrong Joshua, the red you experience is not the same as the red I 
experience.  Although we both absorbed the same wavelength of light, and 
our eyes probably converted the light into similar electrical impulses, no 
two brains are identical (like fingerprints), so those electrical impulses 
are interpreted in unique ways by everybody.

top_comment.text:
I would like to share a theory.. The human eye can tell the difference 
between brightness and darkness. Due to increasing or decreasing of 
brightness, we can determine whether a color is light or dark.. This can be 
measured by observing the reaction of the eye. I won't go as far to say 
that colors like black and white are actual colors, but as humans we can 
agree that the color white is light and the color black is dark.. Probably 
also the lightest and darkest colors we are able to see.

In that case, when looking at this screen on youtube, the background is 
completely white and the white color is represented by RGB colors at its 
highest value (255, 255, 255). This is also a scientific definition, and I 
am not able to teach my brain to do differently. I can't say that other 
colors like orange, purple, and yellow together in even amount, can give 
the color white on the screen.

Therefor I think that we can all agree that Red, Green, and Blue are colors 
that are represented correctly to all of us. What I can't say for sure, is 
whether you see these three colors as I do. Again we can look at the colors 
individually, and perhaps my red colors is not your red color, but as far 
as I can see, the science can tell us that at least Red, Green, and Blue 
are colors that is separated as part of known colors to all of us.

On the other hand, i often experience people having different opinions of 
colors and nuances. For example a very sharp red color, might appear more 
orange to some people than red. Also the turkish colors might seem more 
green to some people while more blue for others.

Colors also have a different approach on people, that is not based on 
individual observation. If you are in a yellow room, you are more likely 
work different, than if you are in a blue room. This is again not something 
you are taught but a psychological observation. 
http://psychology.about.com/od/sensationandperception/a/colorpsych.htm This 
link tells more about how colors can affect our trust and moods and this is 
not something we choose to feel, but is determined by science.

Therefor my conclusion would be, that it is very unlikely that humans 
experience colors differently from each other.

Thanks for reading.﻿

I find it quite freaky when I come across someone whose world view is so 
similar to my own they actually use the same analogies and descriptions of 
perception, and what that actually means.

this is something I feel I arrived at through the independent combination 
of many ideas that I've picked up throughout my life. I know this largely 
comes down to there are accurate ways to describe this way of thinking 
about mind, so ultimately there are only so many combinations of words that 
get the ideas across accurately.

I simplify it down to you can never truly know what someone else's universe 
is like, but you can have a lot of fun interacting with their universe and 
exploring your common symbolism.

top_comment.text:
Color exists outside our brain, it's called a light wave of a specific 
frequency. Proof of this is that it can be pick-up and measured by 
something other than our eyes and brain. We just associate a certain range 
of frequencies, pick-up by our eyes and interpreted by our brain, with 
different names for simplicity. And that is the ONLY thing which can be 
disputed: the NAME associated with the predominant frequency band of light 
that is perceived by someone's brain. Otherwise, astronomers wouldn't be 
able to rely on the color of light to measure and calculate distances 
between galaxies and stars, and be able to tell if they're moving in space 
and at what speeds.﻿

comments.text:
Good point. and I also feel that it brings up interesting problems of 
"evolution" adjustment, so to peak. If dogs are color blind because color 
serves no specific function in their survival, then it makes sense they 
would not develop a need for color. If humans evolved, then why pick color 
as a means of differentiating the objects in their environment? Why not 
"smell" as dogs have done, so they say... If the world is really 
un-colored, it would be a real mystery as to why the mind would "dream up" 
color as a major tenant survival tool. Color has multifaceted functions in 
the life of a human, however, and would seem to be a construct that goes 
beyond the simplicity of mere survival presented by evolutionary theory.

comments.text:
black and white would have to be the exceptions.  what enters our eyes when 
we look at an object is light reflected off of that object. so something we 
perceive as black is absorbing the full spectrum of light, while we see 
white when something is reflecting the full spectrum.  that is why a black 
shirt heats up more than a white one in the summer.  the other colors occur 
when an object is absorbing all of the light except for a specific 
wavelength or frequency that it is reflecting and that we can perceive.  so 
it is probably fairly safe to say that we all see black and white in the 
same way, and where differences could lie is in the perception of the three 
primary colors (yellow, red, and blue).

top_comment.text:
*Is Your Red The Same as My Red?*

Nice philosophical video about concepts that we give labels to but can't 
accurately quantify. We both see a colour and have learned to call it "red" 
but maybe the colour you see is what I would call orange as seen through my 
eyes, or as interpreted by my brain. But we don't have a way in our 
language to describe colours in such a way that even a blind person could 
understand what colours actually mean. 

I also found it interesting when he talked about the meaning of asking 
questions. It shows an understanding of the concept that someone else knows 
information that you yourself do not. And that asking questions is a way to 
get access to that information. What I didn't know is that this is 
something that really separates us from animals, as mentioned in this 
video. ﻿

+Daniel Ely black and white are both physically and biologically different

comments.text:
+ipso246 01 
I don't really understand your question.
You have sensors that react to a certain wavelength band and the way this 
information is interpreted by your brain is largely arbitrary. 
In a certain sense, you perceive such a grayscale. For instance, your eye 
is much more sensitive to red and green light than it is to blue light. 
The answer to your question is simply evolution. It makes sense to 
distinguish colors based on physical properties of objects if it 
contributes to your survival. 
That's the only reason you have eyes in the first place.

comments.text:
When I studied color theory for art, having a scientific background, I 
expanded my study to eventually include how the primary colors were 
determined. Using special tests, they could determine how sensitive the 3 
different color sensors in our eyes are to certain wavelengths of light. 
The sensors' sensitivities varied slightly from one person to another (they 
used the averages for the primary colors). So, we all see slightly 
different, but not significantly different. Your red is not my green, but 
your red may be a TINY bit greener than my red. Saturation and luminosity 
probably similarly vary slightly from person to person.
That is not theory to be contemplated. The research has been foundational 
to many commercial applications. That's still just our perception; all the 
wavelengths of light in the world don't care about our eyes.

Unfortunately, it has not made it into modern art schools (or Vsauce's 
channel apparently). It's the 21st century and the most prestigious art 
schools are still using the "primary colors" from 18th century color theory.

comments.text:
I read through the conversation and I see where it went, but I think in the 
case of the bunny (and the grass) no matter if both appear red, blue, 
green, pink, or plaid, they would by the very act of natural selection be 
similar colors.

Bunnies don't choose what color they are, years of bunnies surviving and 
passing on their genetic makeup that just so happens to make their fur more 
closely resemble the grass does. Their similar color is passed on, no 
matter what that color to you might be.

Like an LED monitor, no two display the same color pixels, but much like 
our eyes they're programmed to interpret a color that is "about" the same. 
Chances are if you're seeing pink bunnies in blue grass, then there's 
something wrong...and the "bunnies" might not be bunnies at all, but 
hallucinations.

To answer VSauce's question: No, we are thus far unable to describe a color 
that one person sees so that they can then see the exact same color.

comments.text:
+ThePolyMath Yes I know. 

I rather like Ramachandran's opinion on qualia:

"I'd like to argue that there is in fact no such barrier, no great vertical 
divide in nature between mind and matter, substance and spirit. Indeed, I 
believe that this barrier is only apparent and that it arises as a result 
of language. This sort of obstacle emerges when there is any translation 
from one language to another.
How does this idea apply to the brain and the study of consciousness? I 
submit that we are dealing here with two mutually unintelligible languages. 
One is the language of nerve impulses - the spatial and temporal patterns 
of neuronal activity that allow us to see red, for example. The second 
language ... is a natural spoken tongue like English or German or Japanese 
..."
p. 231 Phantoms in the Brain

In other words, he says, the problem with qualia is a language barrier. If 
we were to bypass spoken/written language and directly connect the neural 
pathways from my color-processing areas to yours, there would be no 
intermediate language translation. At least in theory, you would see what 
my eyes saw, and know what it's like for me to see red.

"The key idea here is that the qualia problem is not unique to the 
mind-body problem. It is no different in kind from problems that arise from 
any translation, and thus there is no need to invoke a great division in 
nature between the world of qualia and the material world. There is only 
one world with lots of translation barriers. If you can overcome them, the 
problems vanish."
comments.author: Hasan Mohammad

Since color comes from sun rays being broken down by earths atmosphere what 
would happen if our sun was different? Would colors change?﻿
top_comment.author: Jimeng

comments.text:
Our eyes can only see a small part of the elektromagnetic spectrum. This 
spectrum is being created by most stars and a different star would still 
'send out' that spectrum. Now, the colors wouldn't change because the 
objects would still 'reflect' the same wavelenghts as they did before. A 
red car would still reflect the wavelenght our brains interpret as red and 
absorb the other colors if the sun changed. Hope that helped a little:)
comments.author: FearLoathingHolland

comments.text:
No, but if you changed the content of the atmosphere you could make the 
color of the sky change; for example, if you were on Mercury you'd notice 
the sky was black. That's because it has almost no atmosphere to filter and 
scatter the light.

comments.text:
The question here deals with perception, in your mind when you see red, is 
it the same perception as mine? I know that newborns can be tested for 
hearing at a very early age now because we can hook them up to an EEG and 
see if the correct signals are reaching the correct areas of the brain but 
what happens in the brain's interpretation of those sounds is a complete 
mystery. Take for instance synesthesia or more specifically chromesthesia 
 where sounds evoke a sensation or perception of actual color. There are 
people out there that have this and do not know the majority of the 
population do not experience sound in this way.
I always take issue with statements of our knowing something to be true 
because our brains interpret our environment so we may perceive something a 
certain way but that doesn't necessarily make it true.
I like this as a demonstration:
Penn & Teller Explain Ball & Cups on Jonathan Ross 2010.07.09 (Part 2)
You know what is going on, you are told what is going on, you can see what 
is going on, but somehow your brain is still being hacked by these two 
talented magicians. Your mind makes assumptions about what it will see and 
that overrides what you actually see. If you frame flip through the vid 
it's all clear but if you watch it at full speed your mind kicks in and 
does what it does. 
The only things we can say for certain are true are statements about self. 
I like cheese, I feel sad, red to me appears vibrant. 
To some degree we all suffer from some degree of Sally-Ann, believing that 
you experience things the same way that I do.
Sally Anne Test..mpg

The mind is a wonderful playground.
comments.author: Sy Bernot (Psybernaut)

comments.text:
This is interesting but it's mildly explainable in the fact that we 
describe the wavelengths of light(colors) in similar ways right? Red is

comments.text:
Nope. wrong on that on several levels. Just because we have the same 
sensory systems does NOT mean that we all see the same things. And there 
are many things that change the way we see color. There was a study done 
where they should a bunch of American people and some people from some 
tribe somewhere several cards one after the other. Each card had a slightly 
different shade of orange, but then the Americans were shown the cards, 
they all believed them to be the exact same color, "orange". When the 
tribesmen were showed the same cards, they could easily tell the difference 
between the different shades in orange. Why? Because they had words for 
them. When the cards were placed side-by-side, then the Americans could 
easily see the differences in shade, but once they were separated again 
they could no longer "see" the difference in color, even though they knew 
they were different. There has been a HUGE amount of research on how 
language affects what we see and how we see it. So, if just having names 
for slightly different shades of orange can change how we see color, then 
it is by no means unreasonable to think that billions of other factors 
could determine how we see any particular color. And on that note, what 
looks like blue to you may objectively look like your red to someone else, 
but since it's internally consistent in each person's brain, you would 
never know. You'd use the same word to refer to something, and not know 
that it looks completely different to them. And it's something you could 
never know, because there is no objective description of color, because 
that isn't possible.

comments.author: Steven Bowser

comments.text:
+Steven Bowser
Much more goes into it than that. So water is blue, therefor, blue is cool? 
Fire is red, therefor red is hot? These are literary examples used to teach 
young children.
These aren't the actual reasons colors got associations. Most will have to 
with myths and associations with other meanings. Maybe some 
plant/flower/etc was meant to have healing powers. Whatever color this 
plant is might soon be associated with healing/life/etc. Maybe a specific 
flower/gift was commonly used for a certain occasion (wedding/death/etc), 
that color may now represent love, or darkness. Maybe there is a venomous 
snake that is identified by it's color. Even something like water, a 
tropical place might have a different association with blue (water) than 
that of a desert or a tundra.

I'm fairly certain that purple came to be associated with royalty due to 
the fact that purple was an expensive/hard to obtain/create dye, and this 
meant only wealthier people could afford (to waste money on) purple cloth.

Many things come into play. I can assure you that color association is not 
just "Water blue; water is cold; blue now means cold". People (other than 
maybe poets) don't care about things like that. Associations developed for 
actual reasons. Some are bound to overlap between many cultures, and some 
are bound to be distinct. The human brain tries to be smart with the 
connections and associations it makes. So, either the associations were 
taught, or there was an importance to the color for some specific reason. 
Everything is a color, and everything can have hundreds (thousands, 
millions) of associations drawn from it. There needs to be a deep 
importance for an association to connect to an entire culture.
comments.author: as bs

colors we see today are the product of evolution.  Is it inconceivable that 
at some point in our history as a species, we saw only black and white and 
worked our way up slowly from there?  There's still Neanderthal DNA in 
modern humans.  Could colorblindness be an example of old genes that just 
never got eliminated bc there really isn't any major advantage to seeing 
more colors?  Even for me to say "never got eliminated" is kinda stupid. 
 Also, the only reason those fun little "optical illusion" tests for 
colorblindness work is bc the colorblind can see something others can't,

evolution as a viable topic, you have to conclude that color perception is 
stagnant across some species, at the very least. As many insects and other 
prey, such as butterflies, use color as warning signs, creating 
intentionally bright displays of color. Other creatures use color, such as 
with peacocks, for mating and other rituals. In order for these behaviors 
to come about or to even be successful, most, if not all, of that species 
would have to have a general similarity to their perception of color.

comments.text:
+Kaya Hamilton  I think you may be missunderstanding the way colour 
perception works.

Stars don't reflect colour, they emit photons that we perceive as light. 
The light radiation can have variable wavelengths, and this determines the 
colour we perceive the star having ie: blue,red and white stars. Our sun 
for example emits full spectrum 'white light' - Colour is a reflected 
wavelength of light which is emited by a light source and the light source 
doesn't have to be a star.
A green apple absorbs the light that doesn't fit within the spectrum of 
'green', and reflects the green spectrum giving us it's perceived colour.

comments.text:
+Luxai don't be so stubborn; you are making us think that to explain you 
such a simple thing is a colossal task similar to explain what is blue to a 
blind man.

We are mentioning two things here, if colors are real, and they're not 
truly real; and if your brain represents blue for you the same way as my 
brain represents blue for me, and i believe we have different internal 
representations for the same blue.

For the first thing: we have three kind of receptors in our eyes for color, 
not just one, and they're not adjustable, they're fixed to three different 
wavelengths. Said that then to see the color of a ray of light at just one 
wavelength; our eyes take that single signal and convert it into three 
signals, how much red, green and blue is in what we see. This is how we see 
colors. So, when we want to reproduce those colors, e.g., in our computers, 
we use three kinds of light and modify their amplitudes to generate the 
same perception of that color in our eyes... Buuuut, what's on the screen 
is not the same original color; remember, the original thing has only one 
wavelength, not three but we are using three wavelengths now, in each pixel 
on the screen, each wavelength fine tuned to trigger the perception of each 
kind of receptor in our eyes and our brains have no way to know they're 
being tricked... Both signals are very different, but we see them exactly 
the same and call it the same. Colors are a fake thing created by our 
limited perception of the world.

For the second part. Man, your eyes are different than mine, your retina is 
different than mine, your proportion of color receptors is different on 
your retina that on mine, your nerves are wired similarly, but not exactly 
equal as mine and your brain is trained very different by your childhood 
than mine, meaning... you and me have different physical structures, 
similar but different and we still identify blue as blue, that's only 
possible if our brains fine tune our different perceptions, causing our 
brains to use different signals and representations...

comments.text:
+Lucas Alamo No Lucas, this will not prove it. The camera and LCD display 
technology was created by humans. The idea was to capture the colors as 
accurately as possible and then reproduce them on the LCD display in the 
same accurate way. When you say that the camera gathers "it's 
interpretation", this is not completely true. It gathers OUR 
interpretation, because the camera was built so: to gather what people were 
expecting to see as a result.
Same thing with LCD. It was the human who adapted the liquid crystal 
technology, in order to reproduce the colors that he wanted to see on the 
display. The bottom line is that you cannot treat this human built 
technology as an independent observer.
I would define camera+lcd as "image reproducing device". No matter how we 
see the input color, the output color will be the same as the input color.

But, your example this is a very good way to explain the topic to Luxai.
If the image sensor on the camera is our eye that collects the info, and 
the LCD display is what we end up seeing in our conscience, then our brain 
would be the processor in the camera. And the "special effects" of the 
camera would be our topic. If the camera had an effect to swap the colors 
around, then you could relate that to a human that has seen the colors 
differently since day 1.
Sepia effect would be color blindness for some animals and maybe humans, 
then we have black and white effect... Hopefully nobody has fish eye 
effects =)

comments.text:
+Luxai We are not arguing if green is green or not; we are arguing if your 
internal representation of green is the same as my internal representation 
of green. Take the following into consideration:
1) Eyes perceive the colors, but brain is what you use to understand and 
store them. The brain has a different structure than eyes, meaning you have 
to translate the color into an internal representation. Maybe your brain 
does it in a different way.
2) The amount of color recognizer cells in your eyes are different than 
mine. Despite your eyes are sending different signals to your brain than my 
eyes to my brain, we recognize the same color, meaning we translate 
different signals into the same concept.
3) What about people with color blindness? They still recognize some colors 
we also recognize but fail with others... So they have internal 
representations of colors different than us, cause they still see things 
and recognize them.
4) What about people and animals with tetrachromacy? They have four 
different cone cells in they eyes while common people have only three. They 
see some colors we cannot see. I think they use different internal 
structures to represent colors based in a four-tuple rather than me, using 
a three-tuple of data. But they DO see more colors than us cause they 
represent a diferent color specter inside they brains. You can read about a 
woman that sees more colors than us, colors we don't even have a way to 
imagine: http://digitaljournal.com/article/326976.
5) Compare it to another sense, hearing. My brother and i agree in what 
notes does the tetris song have... but i can hear more high pitches than 
him, and he is able to hear some low frequency sound i'm deaf to. That 
means, he have an internal representation for sounds i don't have in my 
brain and i have internal representations of high frequency sounds his 
brain is not aware of. Maybe we just have an internal map of frequencies 
but mine is displaced compared to his map.

information, which could make your "red" different again).

comments.text:
Well, yes, yes you would. Because you guys both would already see the 
colors the same. Think of eyes as the input device. They send electrical 
signals to the brain. These signals can be measured. If you look at the 
same exact thing from the same exact spot, the eyes will send nearly 
identical signals to your brain. Now what happens in your brain is 
according to the 'wiring' of your brain. If your eyes switch, but the brain 
does not, the wiring of your brain is irrelevant.

It's like taking a (identical) picture of something with 2 (different, but 
of the same model) iPhone camera's and looking at the photo's on the same 
monitor. Now, you can mess with the colors of (most) monitors. So if you 
looked at the same photo, with 2 separate monitors, it can look different. 
That said, take a look at any picture on the internet with 20 different 
monitors (all at whatever setting they normally are at) and tell me if any 
of them look like the colors are messed up. Probably not. Just like 
monitors were produced to try and display things a general sort of way, 
brains all work the same in a general sort of way. There are certainly 
people with strange/abnormal brain development, and maybe some of them see 
colors a different way, but if you haven't noticed anything that seems 
strange to you, that seemed normal to literally everyone else, your brain 
is probably producing the same colors as them.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce, Michael here.

This appears blue, this appears yellow, and
this appears green. Those of us with normal

color vision can probably agree. But, that
doesn't change the fact that color is an illusion.

Color, as we know it, does not exist in the
outside world, beyond us, like gravity, or

protons do. Instead, color is created inside
our heads. Our brains convert a certain range

of the electromagnetic spectrum into color.
I can measure the wavelength of radiation,

but, I can't measure, or observe, the experience
of a color inside your mind.

So, how do I know that when you and me look
at a strawberry, and, in my brain, this perception

occurs, which I call "red," that, in your
brain, a perception like this doesn't occur,

which you have, of course, also learned to
call red. We both call it red. We communicate

effectively and walk away never knowing just
how different each of our internal experiences
really were.

Of course, we already know that not everybody
sees color in exactly the same way. One example

would be color blindness. But, we can diagnose
and discuss these differences because people

with the conditions fail to see things that
most of us can.

Conceivably, though, there could be ways of
seeing that we use that cause colors to look

differently in different people's minds, without
altering their performances on any tests we
could come up with.

Of course, if that were the case, wouldn't
some people think other colors look better

than others? Or, that some colors were more
complimentary of others? Well, yeah, but
doesn't that already happen?

This matters because it shows how fundamentally,
in terms of our perceptions, we are all alone
in our minds.

Let's say I met an alien from a far away solar
system who, lucky enough, could speak english,

but had never, and could never, feel pain.
I could explain to the alien that pain is

sent through A-delta and C fibers to the spinal
chord. The alien could learn every single

cell, and pathway, and process, and chemical
involved in the feeling of pain. The alien

could pass a biology exam about pain, and
believe that pain, to us, generally is a bad
thing.

But, no matter how much he learned, the alien
would never actually feel pain. Philosophers

call these ineffable, raw feelings "Qualia."
And our inability to connect physical phenomenon

to these raw feelings, our inability to explain
and share our own internal qualia is known

as the "Explanatory Gap." This gap is confronted
when describing color to someone who's been
blind their entire life.

Tommy Edison has never been able to see. He
has a YouTube channel where he describes what

being blind is like. It's an amazing channel.
In one video he talks about colors, and how

strange, and foreign of a concept it seems
to him. Sighted people try to explain, for

instance, that red is "hot," and blue is "cold."
But, to someone who has never seen a single

color, that just seems weird. And, as he explains,
it has never caused him to finally see a color.

Some philosophers, like Daniel Dennett, argue
that qualia may be private and ineffable simply

because of a failure of our own language,
not because they are, necessarily, always
going to be impossible to share.

There may be an alien race that communicates
in a language that causes colors to appear

in your brain without your retina having to
be involved at all. Or, without you having

to have ever needed actually to see the color
yourself. Perhaps, even in English, he says,

given millions and billions of words used
in just the right way, it may be possible

to adequately describe a color such that a
blind person could see it for the first time.
Or, you could figure out that, once-and-for-all, yes, or, no, in fact, you and your friend
do not see the same red.

But, for now, it remains the case that we
have no way of knowing if my red is the same

as your red. Maybe one day our language will
allow us to share and find out, or, maybe,

it never will. I know it's frustrating to
not have an answer, but, the mere fact that

you guys can ask me about my internal experiences,
and the mere fact that I can ask my friends

and we can all collectively wonder about the
concept of qualia is quite incredible, and
also quite human.

Animals can do all sorts of clever things
that we do. They can use tools, problem solve,

communicate, cooperate, exhibit curiosity,
plan for the future, and, although we can't

know for sure, many animals certainly act
as if they feel emotions- loneliness, fear,
joy.

Apes have even been taught to use language
to talk to us humans. It's a sort of sign

language that they've used to do everything
from answer questions, to express emotion,

or even produce novel thoughts. Unlike any
other animal, these apes are able to understand

language and form responses at about the level
of a 2.5 year old human child.

But, there is something that no signing-ape
has ever done. No ape has ever asked a question.

Joseph Jordania's "Who Asked the First Question?"
is a great read on this topic, and it's available
for free online.

For as long as we've been able to use sign
language to communicate with apes, they have

never wondered, out loud,
about anything that we might know that they
don't.

Of course, this does not mean that apes, and
plenty of other animals, aren't curious. They

obviously are. But, what is suggests is that
they lack a "Theory of Mind": An understanding

that other people have separate minds. That
they have knowledge, access to information

that you might not have. Even us humans aren't
born with a "theory of mind," and there's

a famous experiment to test when a human child
first develops a "theory of mind." It is called
the "Sally-Anne" test.

During the test, researchers tell children
a story about Sally and Anne. Sally and Anne

have a box, and a basket, in their room. They
also happen to have a delicious cookie. Now,

Sally takes the cookie and puts it inside
the box, and then Sally leaves the room. While

Sally is gone, Anne comes over to the box,
takes the cookie out, and puts the cookie

inside the basket. Now, when Sally comes back,
the researchers ask the children "where

will Sally look for the cookie?" Obviously,
Sally will look in the box- that's where she

left it. She has no way of knowing what Anne
did while she was gone. But, until the age

of about 4, children will insist that Sally
will check the basket because, after all,

that's where the cookie is. The child saw
Anne move the cookie, so why wouldn't Sally

also know? Young children fail to realize
that Sally's mental representation of the

situation, her access to information, can
be different than their own.

And apes who know sign language, but never
ask us questions, are doing the same thing.

They're failing to recognize that other individuals
have similar cognitive abilities, and can
be used as sources of information.

So, we are all alone with our perceptions.
We are alone in our own minds. We can both

agree that chocolate tastes good. But, I cannot
climb into your consciousness and experience

what chocolate tastes like to you. I can never
know if my red looks the same as your red.
But, I can ask.

So, stay human, stay curious, and let the
entire world know that you are. And, as always,
thanks for watching.

title: Is Your Red The Same as My Red?
